Question_1.Context: The study focused on the effects of Centella asiatica (CA) on obesity in mice with a high-fat, high-sugar diet. The researchers examined various parameters related to obesity and gene expression in the liver.
Question_1.Question: What was the effect of CA treatment on body weight gain in mice with high-fat, high-sugar diet-induced obesity?
Question_1.B: No effect on body weight gain
Question_1.Source: CA treatment significantly attenuated HFHSD-induced increase in body weight gain (p < 0.05).

Question_2.Context: The study evaluated the impact of CA treatment on serum glucose, triacylglycerol, and cholesterol levels in mice with high-fat, high-sugar diet-induced obesity.
Question_2.Question: How did CA treatment affect serum glucose levels in mice with high-fat, high-sugar diet-induced obesity?
Question_2.B: No effect on serum glucose levels
Question_2.Source: CA treatment attenuated HFHSD-induced increase in serum glucose levels, with CA-H showing significantly lower levels compared to HFHSD (p < 0.05).

Question_3.Context: The researchers measured the relative weights of different white adipose tissues (WAT) in mice with high-fat, high-sugar diet-induced obesity treated with CA.
Question_3.Question: Which white adipose tissue showed a significant reduction in relative weight with CA treatment?
Question_3.D: No significant reduction in any WAT
Question_3.Source: CA treatment significantly reduced the relative weight of inguinal WAT in mice with HFHSD-induced obesity (p < 0.05).

Question_4.Context: The study included histological analysis of liver and epididymal white adipose tissue (eWAT) in mice with high-fat, high-sugar diet-induced obesity treated with CA.
Question_4.Question: What was the effect of CA treatment on hepatic steatosis in mice with high-fat, high-sugar diet-induced obesity?
Question_4.Source: CA treatment markedly reduced hepatic steatosis in mice with HFHSD-induced obesity.

Question_5.Context: The researchers evaluated the mRNA expression levels of various genes related to cholesterol homeostasis and lipid metabolism in the liver of mice with high-fat, high-sugar diet-induced obesity treated with CA.
Question_5.Question: How did CA treatment affect the mRNA expression levels of PPARγ in the liver?
Question_5.Source: CA treatment significantly attenuated the mRNA expression levels of PPARγ in the liver of mice with HFHSD-induced obesity (p < 0.05).

Question_6.Context: The study aimed to understand the mechanisms involved in the anti-obesity effects of CA by examining various parameters in mice with high-fat, high-sugar diet-induced obesity.
Question_6.Question: What was the impact of CA treatment on adipocyte diameter in epididymal white adipose tissue (eWAT)?
Question_6.Source: CA treatment attenuated HFHSD-induced increase in adipocyte diameter in eWAT, with CA-H showing significantly smaller diameter compared to HFHSD (p < 0.001).

Question_7.Context: The study examined the effects of CA treatment on body fat accumulation and gene expression in the liver of mice with high-fat, high-sugar diet-induced obesity.
Question_7.Question: What was the effect of CA treatment on the mRNA expression levels of FAS in the liver?
Question_7.Source: CA treatment significantly attenuated the mRNA expression levels of FAS in the liver of mice with HFHSD-induced obesity (p < 0.01).

Question_8.Context: The researchers investigated the ameliorative effects of CA in vivo to understand the underlying mechanisms involved in the anti-obesity effects of CA.
Question_8.Question: How did CA treatment affect the macrovesicular area of epididymal white adipose tissue (eWAT)?
Question_8.Source: Compared to that in the HFHSD, macrovesicular area of eWAT was decreased following CA treatment (p < 0.05).

Question_9.Context: The study aimed to provide scientific evidence supporting CA as a supplement to prevent obesity by examining various parameters in mice with high-fat, high-sugar diet-induced obesity.
Question_9.Question: What was the effect of CA treatment on serum triacylglycerol levels in mice with high-fat, high-sugar diet-induced obesity?
Question_9.B: No effect on serum triacylglycerol levels
Question_9.Source: CA treatment attenuated HFHSD-induced increase in serum triacylglycerol levels, with CA-H showing significantly lower levels compared to HFHSD (p < 0.05).

Question_10.Context: The researchers examined the effects of CA treatment on various parameters related to obesity and gene expression in the liver of mice with high-fat, high-sugar diet-induced obesity.
Question_10.Question: How did CA treatment affect the mRNA expression levels of CD36 in the liver?
Question_10.Source: CA treatment significantly attenuated the mRNA expression levels of CD36 in the liver of mice with HFHSD-induced obesity (p < 0.05).
